I blew through this fascinating audiobook, practically manufacturing housework to do so that I'd have an excuse to plug myself in (okay, that's a bit of an exaggeration; there was plenty of housework to do without my having to manufacture any). I would recommend this book to just about anyone seeking a great read -- even if you're usually more of a fiction person, this non-fiction book offers plenty of interesting characters and storylines as well as being informative and provocative in the way of non-fiction.Did you know that much of medical research (and the benefits we derive every day, including many routine vaccines and medications we take for granted) is dependent on a culture of human cells that continue to live and reproduce even after their original owner died in 1951? Well, I didn't. And I wouldn't have thought that this factoid would interest me particularly, not being much of a science person myself. But somehow, Rebecca Skloot was able to make the dynamics surrounding these cells not only comprehensible to me but intriguing (no small feat). Even more intriguing, though, was the story of the late human being behind these cells, Henrietta Lacks, who never knew that her cells had been taken for research. Henrietta's surviving children, tragically losing their mother at a young age to cervical cancer and raised in a poor and abusive environment, only learned about this later in life and never saw a penny of the proceeds."The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks" contains several stories. There is the story of Henrietta, a poor young African American woman with incurable cervical cancer, and of her children struggling to grow up without her after her early death. There is the story of the doctor who decided to slice off pieces of her tumor just prior to her death without asking or even informing her, who then discovered that these cancerous cells were immortal. There is the story of the cells, which began to be mass-produced and distributed to researchers for a wide variety of interesting and often ground-breaking experiments. And there is the story of Rebecca Skloot, a journalist who was persistent and dogged in her efforts to win Henrietta's family's reluctant trust (after they had been duped by others attempting to capitalize on Henrietta) so that she could learn and tell their story.Henrietta's adult children in this book are colorful characters with their own stories who overcame some difficult situations, some more successfully than others. We also meet different doctors and researchers -- while some prove to be profiteers, others are truly dedicated to science for its own sake. The doctor who originally took Henrietta's tumor for research without her knowledge fell into the latter category, which is part of what makes this a three-dimensional book rather than a simplistic polemic. A product of his times, this 1950s doctor was less sensitive to the medical and research ethics which have since received more attention, particularly when it came to a poor African-American woman. Should you care if someone uses your body tissues for medical research without your consent? Before I began reading this book, my thought was, why the heck would I care? Assuming that these tissues need to be removed in any case, why not use them to do some good for science and for mankind? But Rebecca offers some anecdotes which complicate this question, and the irony running throughout the book is that Henrietta's descendants cannot afford decent medical care, even as the entire medical profession benefits from Henrietta's unwittingly donated cells.Even if you think you're not a science person, even if you think you're not a non-fiction person, I would recommend checking this book out.

On the threshold between medicine and ethics.This book talks about ethical and legal conflicts, historically raised by the discovery of immortal cells that changed medicine and patients life's for the better. It‘s an astonishing story you probably didn‘t hear about before:In 1951 a colored poor woman named Henrietta Lacks walked into the Hopkins University, where a doctor extracted cells from her large cervix tumor, that killed her briefly after. But as they discovered in the laboratory, those were anything but normal cells, but the first immortal human cells grown in culture. They are still alive today and were replicated to millions and spread to laboratories all over the world, though Lacks has been dead for more than sixty years. They called them HeLa cells and they were vital for developing the polio vaccine; uncovered secrets of cancer, viruses, and the atom bomb’s effects; helped lead to important advances like in vitro fertilization, cloning, and gene mapping; and have been bought and sold by the billions. What interested me the most was the scientific and legal part of that book. Ultimately it‘s a question of property and if we have the right on our cells, once they leave our body, particularly if we don‘t know about it.First there is the problem with uninformed consent. Henrietta did not provide informed consent for her cells to be used, she didn‘t have knowledge. Beyond that people were later unknowingly injected with her tumor cells, for the purpose of medical research. The same was performed on healthy prisoners with their knowledge, though their free consent seems to be questionable. They developed tumors, sometimes killing them. Furthermore her autopsy report was later published in the book of a journalist, the family didn‘t knew about and didn‘t want to see published. The question is the violation of privacy rights.The second problem are genetic rights/non-rights. Her family (whose DNA also links to those cells) did not learn of the implications of her tissue sample until years later, and didn‘t fully approve of it‘s usage A big focus also are patents and profits for biologic material.Henrietta and her family were very poor and didn’t even have health insurance. They received zero profits, while her cells sell for multiple-millions until today.Very shocking are also racism claims. Because the cells were discovered in the 50, making public that white people were treated with cell stems of a black woman would have had a major impact. Additionally implications are made, that colored people were categorically abused, abducted, purposely infected and killed to perform medical experiments. The biographical nature of the book ensures the reader does not separate the science and ethics from the family. These are not abstract questions, impacts and implications, but actual, valuable people and historic events.What I didn’t like just as much though, is how the story is told at times, jumping between characters and writing styles; sometimes loosing the silver lining. The writing is very simple and doesn’t at all feel factual. As a non fiction fan, I miss that at times but I guess that others appreciate it even more. It reads a lot like a novel, particularly since a lot of content is told through conversations. In conclusion a super interesting story I won’t forget quickly!

This is one stellar piece of nonfiction that has a bit of everything in it for everybody. Beautifully written and structured because it is clear that while there's SOoo much information here, it is arranged in such a way that you don't get lost. Sure the author is a science writer, but she's also a creative nonfiction writer so the book doesn't read like a nonfiction textbook, and has the plot structure of fiction. Some chapters tell the story of Henrietta Lacks and her family, others take you on the research journey with Rebecca Skloot. The interactions she has with the family makes for light, sometimes humorous reading. In fact, the chronology is done in a way to make the book more interesting. The book is as much about family, as it is about science, history, racial tensions, and of one extraordinary black woman who has done more for medical research and advancements, than anything or anyone the industry has seen. It will have you crying, laughing, yelling at people...you name it. Born in 1920, Henrietta Lacks was thirty years old when she went to see a doctor for "spotting" and pain, and started getting treatments for cervical cancer (mind you, in the "colored" wards of John Hopkins. This was during the Jim Crow era). The researcher/doctor who treated her, collected samples of her cells (without her knowledge) while he placed radium inside of her. She soon deteriorated and each time she went in for treatment, her cells were taken and stored. Yet she knew nothing of the cells growing in a lab, or the fact that she was now infertile because of her cancer treatment. When she died, her husband signed paperwork to have an autopsy performed, because he was under the impression that doctors would find out if his children were predisposed to whatever his wife had, not knowing that his signature allowed his wife's body to be cut open to help with more research.This is the breadth of the story I think. A story about an African-American woman whose life and death seemed to be an irony--she wasn't allowed to mention her white, slave-owning family, yet she was buried next to them. She wasn't allowed to use the "white-only" medical facilities, yet her cells were mixed with white cells. In science cell culture, there were no other cells with the ability to multiply and stay immortal like hers. So every major medical breakthrough, like polio vaccine for example, came from the usage of her cells. The main thrust is, she didn't know. Her family didn't know, and they didn't find out until twenty years later because the name Henrietta Lacks was hidden by the doctors who used her cells as research. Scientists made millions from her body and her family had tons of health issues, with no help from their mother's cells and no health insurance. "A search of U.S. Patent and Trademark Office database turns up more than seventeen thousand patents involving HeLa Cells," Skloot wrote. But Henrietta's son Lawrence wanted to know, "She's the most important woman in the world and her family living in poverty. If our mother is so important to science, why can't we get health insurance?"There they were, at a time when the country was learning about the "Tuskegee Syphilis Study" (where African-American men with syphilis were recruited for research, then made to die slow, painful deaths even after their researchers realized that penicillin would cure them), and cells from a black woman was being used to save millions of Americans, mostly white.In this book, Skloot brings the woman behind the cells to life, talks about her life, her troubled marriage, her children. She develops a relationship with Deborah, Henrietta's daughter who suffered the most from all of it. She talks to scientists and researchers. She brings in history. She talks about race tensions and shows how when slavery was abolished, African-Americans became slaves to another master: medicine. I'll admit, at times it was an emotional roller coaster for me, but one quote from Deborah stood out for me and should for you:"Like I'm always telling my brothers, if you gonna go into history, you can't do it with a hate attitude. You got to remember, times was different."So anybody should be able to read this book because the way in which it is written, is not to point fingers (not even at the medical industry because the author manages to explain those times as well) but to glean the truth. To finally give credit where credit is due, and to educate. To honor a woman, a mother, a wife, whose body makes it possible for us to get some of the modern medical treatments that we get today. This is one book I will remember, that's for sure!

In 1951, Henrietta Lacks passed away due to complications arising from cervical cancer. Following her death, cancerous cells were harvested from her body and used in ongoing experiments regarding the growth of cells outside the human body. Previous to Henrietta, scientists could only make it a few days before the cells would ultimately die, forcing them to start all over. Henrietta’s cells were different, they grew at an astounding rate and researchers were able to keep them alive. Since the discovery, they've been used in countless experiments and led to numerous scientific breakthroughs - most notably the polio vaccine.Today, Henrietta’s cells usually go for a few hundred dollars a vial but her descendants live in poverty. While many of her children believe they should be compensated for the sale of HeLa cells, court cases involving similar claims have always found in favor of research companies rather than individuals - the argument being that once a procedure is performed and tissue is removed from a body, it is no longer of use to the individual and the hospital can do with it as it pleases, be it incineration or study. On one hand, it makes sense given that it was highly doubtful Henrietta’s husband could have opened a cellular research facility, however, the problem lies within the fact that researchers did not tell Henrietta’s family about the importance of HeLa cells and lied to her children when additional bloodwork was requested for further study.The story of the Lacks family is a heartbreaking one. Henrietta had a terrible upbringing and following her death, things became that much worse for her children. While the book mainly concentrates on the HeLa cells, there’s a shocking piece on her daughter Elsie, who had been diagnosed with “idiocy” and institutionalized at Crownsville Hospital Centre (a.k.a. The Hospital for the Negro Insane) following her mother’s death. The conditions at the time of Elsie’s arrival were deplorable. They had a total of eight attendants (four in the day, four in the evening) for five hundred and sixty patients. One ward in particular had seventy eight patients with only twenty eight beds. There were also only three toilets to share amongst them all. You can imagine how much this upset the family when they found out decades later.While The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks can be deeply upsetting, it is without a doubt an important book. Author Rebecca Skloot spent years interviewing the Lacks family (which at times was certainly no easy task) and researching Henrietta’s life and death, all information that had been buried over time. The story flows well and her afterword provides greater insight into the legal ramifications of future soft tissue research. Henrietta’s youngest daughter Deborah always wanted the world to know about the person behind the HeLa cells, the real human being who provided the ammunition for several medical discoveries. Thanks to Rebecca’s tireless work, Henrietta Lacks' incredible true story is out there for the world to see.Also posted @ Every Read Thing.

“Henrietta’s (cells) were different: they reproduced an entire generation every twenty-four hours, and they never stopped. They became the first immortal human cells ever grown in a laboratory.”  Argh, I feel embarrassed admitting this, but before reading this book, I had no idea what the HeLa cells were. I never studied science in-depth, which is now one of my biggest regrets. However, I guess in some ways I was lucky: I got to know who Henrietta Lacks was before meeting her famous cells. In this well-researched biography, Rebecca Skloot tells the story of Henrietta Lacks, a poor Black woman who was only 31 when she died from cervical cancer. While she was getting treatments at John Hopkins Hospital, Dr. George Guy took cells from Lack’s tumor without her consent. After examining her cells, Guy felt amazed. He realized her cells were unlike any he had seen - Henrietta’s cells refused to die.HeLa would become the first immortal cell line grown in a lab. For scientists, this discovery was monumental. It would allow them to conduct experiments they never could before. Henrietta’s cells would later help create in vitro fertilization, polio vaccines, and cancer treatments. Although HeLa cells have affected each of us in different ways, before this book’s publication, most of us had little to no idea who Henrietta Lacks was.Here is what I found riveting: Henrietta never graduated from high school, yet she became one of the most important people in science. Sure, science has its own explanation for how this happened, but her family believed God chose Henrietta. God wanted her to come back to Earth in the form of her cells to help others. Since the Lacks had a weak science background, faith was their way of understanding what happened to Henrietta, and making sense of the non-sensical. Though most of the Lacks were happy Henrietta’s cells were advancing science, some of them were mad. The Lacks had no science education, and scientists never bothered to explain to them what happened to Henrietta in a simple way. Researchers exploited their ignorance and the Lacks were never able to give informed consent. Their frustrations are understandable. I felt like giving each of them a hug when I read these passages. If I were them, I would be upset too. While HeLa cells were becoming a multi-million dollar industry, the Lacks were living in poverty, barely able to afford health insurance:   “...the last thing he remembered before falling into unconsciousness under anesthesia was a doctor standing over him saying his mother's cells were one of the most important things that had ever happened to medicine. Sonny woke up more than $125,000 in debt because he didn't have health insurance to cover the surgery.”  I also admire Skloot's grit because this was a massive project to undertake. I can understand why this book took her a decade to write. I think she wanted to do Henrietta's story justice, and she did. Skloot made sure the world knew about the Lacks and what they did for science. Furthermore, I liked that Skloot’s discussed the social determinants of health. Her clear prose helped me better understand patient rights, inequalities in medicine, informed consent, and tissue ownership laws. Overall, “The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks" was a magnificent treat. I am positive other readers will find this book as informative and awe-inspiring as I did.

Skloot delivers a mix of science history and human interest in her journalistic style. She discusses medical ethics particularly the issue of informed consent as she tells the story of Henrietta Lacks. Henrietta was a poor black woman who joined the great migration of the 1940’s moving from rural southern Virginia to Baltimore, Maryland. She was treated for cervical cancer at Johns Hopkins, the only nearby hospital that would admit blacks in 1951. After suffering through the then standard radium therapy, she died that same year. Samples of her tumor were removed and became the first successful human cell culture to sustain itself. Known as HeLa her cells live on today in labs around the world the subject of endless experimentation. Most of the book is spent on Henrietta’s life, her daughter Deborah, their families and extended relations as well as the author’s work with the family to research the book. We follow Henrietta from her childhood in the 1920’s growing up in former slave quarters on the wrong side of the tracks in the small tobacco country town of Clover, Virginia. Skloot gives a somewhat romanticized version of what must have been a harsh life of poverty and discrimination. Similarly Skloot tries to bring out the positives while dutifully reporting the difficult lives of Henrietta’s descendants who suffer from chronic mental and physical illnesses, limited education and continued discrimination in the Baltimore area. Particularly interesting to me was the communication gap between the scientists and Henrietta’s working class African American family. A big part of the problem was the history of exploitation of African Americans by white doctors and their medical institutions. This history had been internalized into a pervasive distrust of doctors and hospitals by Henrietta’s family. Henrietta’s and her family’s fear is understandable and it struck me as part of a broader issue. With unarmed black men dying regularly at the hands of the police, we see similar fears by African Americans today. Skloot points out that scientific progress was made from practices that now would be clearly unethical. Henrietta’s cells sped up the development of the Polio vaccine in the early 1950’s saving many from this devastating disease. Concepts such as informed consent did not exist in 1951. Even today the issue is very murky which the author addresses in her afterword. At the end of the book Skloot returns to Clover to find it gone. All the ramshackle old buildings torn down, just empty fields remaining. Most of those who knew Henrietta had now passed on too. Only her cells remain, thriving in labs everywhere and generating the ground breaking medical discoveries of a new era.

In the same way we sometimes debate whether the story should be seen as an entirely seperate entity to the writer, so too do scientists perceive a sample of cell tissue as seperate to the human body it was extracted from. Except that it is not possible to extract a story from a writer's imagination without their consent. Henrietta Lacks was a young mother in her early thirties when she was diagnosed with an aggressive form of cancer that would quickly take her life. She was fortunate to live close to the John Hopkins hospital, set up to ensure equal access to medical care for all' no matter their race, status, income or any other characteristic that might have otherwise given cause to discriminate.Before undergoing treatment, one of the Doctors took a tissue sample of her healthy cells and the cancerous cells, as he had been doing to most patients, in an effort to try and find cells that would continue to replicate without dying - the elusive "immortal" cell. It had never been done successfully with human cells before.He succeeded and the cells became known the world over as he gave them away freely, known as HeLa cells, the immortal human cells that never died and could be used over and over again to test for cures to disease and to observe how cells react to numerous variables, furthering science in ways unimaginable previously. Few paused to ask who the woman behind these cells was, what was her story, how did her family feel about this multi million dollar research industry that was making great strides in science yes, and also making entrepreneurial types wealthy in the process.Rebecca Skloot made Henrietta the subject of her research for 10 years in the creation of this thorough, respectful account of the life of Henrietta Lacks and her journey to uncover the events of the time within the context of what was the norm in her day. In much of it she is accompanied by Henriettas daughter Deborah, a passionate woman who was unable to find peace in her own life, until she had helped bring her mother's story to light.A brilliant and informative story and piece of scientific medical history that reads like a novel and brings our awareness to the many who unknowingly make sacrifices for the better of others and that always present aspect of those hovering in the wings, recognising an opportunity to profit.

“Everybody in the world got her cells, only thing we got of our mother is just them medical records and her Bible.”
In 1951 doctors at Johns Hopkins in Baltimore diagnosed an unusually extreme case of cervical cancer. The breakneck growth rate and resistance to common remedies were unlike anything previously seen. Without informed consent, the doctor scraped a clump of cells from the cancerous tumor during one of the 30 year-old woman’s visits and deposited them with a nearby cell culture lab operated by George Gey. There, in the air-controlled space of Gey’s facility, something happened that researchers had long suspected out of reach. Where countless other cells before them had died, hers survived, and multiplied indefinitely. The immortality of this one cell line would prove instrumental in treating a number of the world’s most heavy-hitting diseases and set the stage for an all new era in cell research, medical diagnosis, drug development and bioethics. But this is a story not just about bundles of cells, but about the humanity behind them, and in particular the family to which they will forever be tied.That woman was Henrietta Lacks. Henrietta passed away just nine months after diagnosis, but it would be more than two decades before her family received word of the namesake cell line which survived her—HeLa. Its value as a scientific and commercial commodity was paramount, getting bogged down in the thicket of rights and privacy less so. Once researchers discovered that Henrietta’s cells did not die but instead bred a new generation every twenty-four hours, HeLa quickly became the tireless workhorse of the culture community. Vials were trucked to research facilities around the world, where they were regularly exposed to a pavilion of infectious diseases, merged with non-human DNA, and even shot into space in an effort to study the influence of zero gravity.Over time, details about the parent of the eponymous cells funneled out of view. Henrietta’s own kin were oblivious to the fact that her cells lived, were being studied and tested in dozens of countries, and were being exchanged at great profit. Once the unwitting donor’s official name was released, journalists descended in full fervor, leading to a lifetime of turmoil and unrest for the Lacks household. Set against the rich legacy of the family’s cells, their life of poverty and unpaid medical bills seemed untoward by comparison, and this sense of injustice only mounted as more details filtered in from the press.Rebecca Skloot’s segue into this lush narrative was by and large a product of serendipitous circumstance, having first heard of HeLa in an intro to biology course at her local community college. After learning that these cells had lived outside their host's body for the better part of a century, and about the remarkable advances they have gifted to science, Skloot shot up her hand and innocently asked, "Who was she?" The professor's reply proved unsatisfying: "An African American woman." The seed of curiosity had been planted. By the time Skloot graduated she'd decided to write a book to recover the disremembered woman whose cells had won so many victories for science and society.Who Was Henrietta Lacks?For more than a decade, Skloot layered herself into the Lacks’ story, befriending and forming deep bonds with Henrietta’s children and cousinry. She forges an especially strong connection with Deborah Lacks, Henrietta’s youngest daughter, who was unfortunately too young to remember much about her mother. With a mix of patience and persistence the two work together to dig up Henrietta’s heritage and bring to light her hitherto uncelebrated legacy. It is Skloot’s at times unstable relationship and camaraderie with Deborah that gives the narrative its steam, as the two probe ever deeper into the mystery surrounding her mother.Tracing the family’s roots places Henrietta’s childhood at the tail end of the Jim Crow era, a time when segregation meant a great deal more than which bathroom and water fountain one was required to use. Rampant legal disadvantages in the South bred systemic, institutionalized maladjustment for blacks, and this included limited access to medical care. Having spent her youth on a slave plantation in Clover, Virginia, Henrietta joined in the Great Migration at the ripened age of twenty-one, exchanging her familiarity with tobacco fields for a new life in Baltimore. Nine years later, she would be diagnosed with the malignancy that led to her iconic cell line. And it would be another fifty years before Deborah, with the help of Skloot, laid eyes on her mother’s original medical records.Johns Hopkins Hospital was founded for the express purpose of treating Baltimore's poor and, unlike today, informed consent upon providing blood or tissue samples was neither required by law nor common practice (the term did not even appear in a court document until 1957). Like everyone at the time, Henrietta hadn't a clue about what would become of her excised genetic material and the boons it would lavish upon the scientific community. This became a flashpoint issue in the years that followed as the occasional patient attempted to turn a gray area into a lucrative venture. While we learned more about DNA and transmissible disease, Henrietta's resilient cells inaugurated an international conversation on the commercialization of biological materials and where exactly the donors fit within that ecosystem. In many ways, the conversation is ongoing. (Skloot includes a superb summary in the afterword which draws together the various threads of this nuanced debate.) The HeLa LegacyTo properly gauge the vastitude of the legacy tied up in Henrietta’s cells, it’s important to understand 20th century cell culture. Until Henrietta came along, cell immortality was a pipe dream. While standard, non-cancerous cells had been grown in vitro since 1907, none of them survived long enough to endure important testing, petering out after 50 divisions, on average. Even cancer cells, like those common to cervical cancers, died shortly after relocation to the culture environment. This meant not only was there a brief window for experimentation but that a continuous supply of fresh cells was needed to sustain research. Many in the field yearned for a better way.HeLa keynoted a paradigm shift. They were robust enough to survive in the bricolage of materials used in Dr. Gey’s culture medium, and they were susceptible to the same range of infectious diseases as were normal cells. This allowed researchers to inject the lively DNA with diseases as well as cures. Not merely a boon to science, this revolutionized the field, so much so that one of the researchers Skloot interviews in the book, when asked what would happen if HeLa was pulled from research use, replied, “Restricting HeLa cell use would be disastrous. The impact that would have on science is inconceivable.” (p. 328)Thanks to Dr. Gey’s partnering efforts with labs around the globe, the benefits of HeLa manifested seemingly overnight. In just one year after HeLa’s genesis, Jonas Salk and his team were able to derive a vaccine for polio by infecting HeLa cells, followed shortly by drug treatments for HPV, herpes, leukemia, influenza, hemophilia and Parkinson’s disease. In 1953 HeLa became the first cells to be cloned successfully. In total, some 60,000 papers have been published on HeLa, and cell culturists still use her cancer cells as a model for human biology.What was it exactly that gave HeLa cells their added dose of moxie? Even today, we can only speculate. We now know that Henrietta was infected with both HPV and syphilis, so one theory is that this virulent combination may have helped suppress PCD. A rival theory suggests she had highly atypical genes to begin with, perhaps a rare mutation, that enabled the cancer to spiral in unspecified directions. We still are uncertain. HeLa has also been the source of much frustration over the years from regularly contaminating other cell lines, often halting research until the botch-up is sorted.Closing ThoughtsRebecca Skloot’s ten-year effort is a literary and cultural marvel balanced between unsheathing the posthumous success and humanity behind one of the richest narratives in science and laying bare the bioethical implications to which it is attached. It succeeds on both fronts. Skloot is at her most animating when channeling the lens of Deborah Lacks as they band together to reach some much-needed closure to the saga thrust upon the Lacks family. With her first book, Skloot has demonstrated in equal measure her facility for conveying scientific nuance while weaving meaning and poetic force into a cohesive whole. Yes, this is first and foremost a work of nonfiction, but its pages are emblazoned with enough touches of novel-like charisma to beckon both crowds. The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks is a timeless story delivered by a gifted writer and the definitive presentation of the legacy Henrietta never lived to see. Highly recommended.Skloot also founded The Henrietta Lacks Foundation - click here for more - to provide support for the Lacks as well as assistance to African Americans pursuing education in science and medicine. A portion of her book’s proceeds are donated to the Foundation.Note: This review is republished from my official website. Click through for additional footnotes and imagery.

In The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks (ILHL), Skloot blends the Lacks' family history with that of medical sciences and all against a backdrop of systemic racism. For decades, her cell line, named HeLa, has far eclipsed the woman of their origin. Henrietta Lacks was born in 1920 as the ninth child of Eliza and Johnny Pleasant in Roanoke, Virginia. When Eliza died after birthing her tenth child in 1924, the family was divided amongst the larger network of relatives who pitched in to raise the children. Henrietta and David Lacks, her first cousin and future spouse, were raised together by their grandfather Tommy in a former slaves quarter cabin in Lacks Town (Clover), Virginia. Lacks Town had been the inheritance carved out of Henrietta's white great grandfather Albert Lacks' tobacco plantation in the late 1800s.From Skloot's interviews with relatives, Henrietta was a generously hospitable, hard working, and loving mother whose premature death led to enormous consequences for her children. Henrietta suspected a health problem a year before her fifth and last child was born. She went to Johns Hopkins, a renowned medical institution and a charity hospital, in Baltimore and received a diagnosis of cervical cancer in January 1951. (view spoiler)[Since cervical cancer is caused by a sexually transmitted virus, it seems likely that she had contracted the virus from her husband, who had not been monogamous. (hide spoiler)]During her first treatment for cancer, malignant cells were removed - without Henrietta's knowledge - and cultivated in a lab environment by Johns Hopkins researchers attempting to uncover cancer's secrets. Although the brachytherapy with radium was initially deemed a success, Henrietta's brown skin turned black as the cancer aggressively metastasized. After several weeks of great pain, Henrietta died in October 1951.ILHL raises questions about the extent to which we own our bodies, informed consent, and ethics surrounding the research of anything human. The HeLa line was a rare scientific success as those malignant cells thrived in lab conditions and eventually became crucial to thousands of research projects. Skloot reported that in 2009, an average human body was worth anywhere from $10,000 to $150,000. In the case of John Moore who had leukemia, his cell line was valued in millions of dollars. To prevent human trafficking, it is illegal to sell human organs and tissues, but they can be donated while processing fees are assessed.As a charity hospital in the 1950s, segregated patient wards in Johns Hopkins were filled with African Americans whose tissue samples were regarded by researchers as "payment." One cannot "donate" what one doesn't know. The Lacks family discovered HeLa's existence 22 years after Henrietta died. They've struggled to pay their medical costs while biotechnology companies have reaped profits from cultivating and selling HeLa cells. In 1999, the Rand Corporation estimated that 307 million tissue samples from  178 million  people (almost 60 percent of the population) were stored in the US for research purposes. Although the US is nowhere close to definitively addressing the questions raised by ILHL , a little progress has been made. In 1974, the Federal Policy for Protection of Human Subjects (the "Common Rule") required informed consent for federally funded research. The Common Rule was passed in response to egregious and inhumane experiments such as the Tuskegee Syphilis project and another scientist who wanted to know whether injecting people with HeLa would give them cancer. Note that this rule exempts privately funded research. In 1996, the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) made it illegal for health practitioners and insurers to make one's medical information public without their consent. This was after researchers had published medical information about the Lacks family. It should be evident that human tissues have long been monetized. One method of creating monopoly - like control has been to obtain a patent. As of 2005, the US has issued patents for about 20 percent of all known human genes. Myriad Genetics patented two genes - BRCA1 and BRCA2 - indicative of breast and ovarian cancer. In 2009 the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU), on behalf of scientists, sued Myriad Genetics. In 2013, the US Supreme Court gave the victory to the ACLU and invalidated the patents, thus lowering future research costs and obliquely taking a step toward defining ownership of the human body.

Henrietta Lacks was a mother to four children and about to become one for the fifth time when she started to feel sick. After the birth of her son, she only grew sicker. At John Hopkins, she was diagnosed with cervical cancer and underwent treatment. Unfortunately, the cancer spread quickly and Henrietta died. Before her death, a sample of her cancerous tissue was taken and cultivated in the lab. Her cells grew at an unprecedated rate and became extremely valuable to the scientific realm. Called HeLa, Henrietta's cells were the first to reach "immortality". Her family did not know this information for several years. This is the story of the woman behind the cells.I began reading more non-fiction books last year and have since come across some amazing works. 'The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks' will join those ranks. Hands down, this is one of the best non-fiction books written. Broad-in-scope, thought-provocking, awe-inspiring and jaw-dropping, this book is the perfect marriage between science and human interest. Greatly researched and with much heart, the prose is magnificent. Henrietta Lacks was a poor tobacco farmer, descended from slaves. When she was diagnosed with cervical cancer, she did not particularly stand out but when her cancerous tissue was cultivated in the Hopkins lab, that was a different story. Until HeLa, scientists had not been able to produce a cell line that perdured. With HeLa cells, however, they hit the jackpot. Used in everything from the development of vaccines to genetic research and even to test out the effects of a nuclear bomb, the impact of these cells is immesurable. Just one problem, Henrietta did not give consent to give her cells and her family did not learn of just how important Henrietta was until many years after her death. About 50 miillion metric tons of HeLa cells have been produced to date, more than enough cells to populate a village full of Henriettas. While Henritta never travelled far form her home, her cells have been all over the world and even into outer space. They have been infected with several illnesses and combined with other cells. Odds are eah of us has, in some way, come in contact with HeLa.The way in which Skloot balances the science aspect with the human asprct of the book is done with finnesse. The HeLa cells are something impressive but more so is the woman behind them. Henrietta was strong, confident and resourceful. By all accounts, she faced her cancer diagnosis with sheer bravery and never stopped thinking about her family, even when she knew she would not survive. Its truly sad that for that Henriettas's cells did for the world, her heirs do not even know where the exact location of her grave is. What stood out for me most was the relationship that developed between Sloot and Deborah (Henrietta's daughter). Until Skloot, most were merely interested in the cells with Henrietta as an afterthought. I love that Skloot focused on Henrietta. Its time she gets the recognition that is way overdue.This work raises many questions. With the "Tissue Issue", consent and scientific progress are at a standstill. Henrietta's cells were taken without her knowledge or that of her family. The exact amount of money made off the HeLa cells is not known but its exorbitant. Her family never saw a cent and sadly struggle to pay their health insurance. Biological ownership is a tricky subject matter. The John Moore case was one of the cases that put it on the map and it has been a hot botton issue since. While there are some basic rules to follow, the gist is that once any tissue is "abandoned" at a hospital, it ceases to be property of the patient. Blood tests, biopsies and tissue taken from surgeries are property of the hospital and they have no obligation to let their patients know if and for what their tissues can be used. The scientific communty argues that to seek consent would lead to a decreased access to materials or have people seek financial gain. Personally, I find this troubling. The moral and ethical concerns are overwhelming and getting to an agreement between both parties is a battle. Scientific progress is important but at what cost? This is a book that will stay with me for a while. Its up there with 'The Radium Girls' (another great non-fiction work). Highly recommended!

2.5 stars. I found the 1st 1/2 of this book fascinating and eagerly awaited to hear more of Henrietta's story. Henrietta was someone you couldn't help but root for and you were amazed to hear of her strength and perpetual optimism. The 2nd 1/2 of this book was tedious and annoying. The book started to drag and focus too much on the researcher's hardships, but mostly, I found Henrietta's family to be utterly unlikable. I kept thinking of that saying, "I can explain it to you, but I can't understand it for you". I felt much of the Lacks family, particularly Deborah and Joe (who changed his name to the long Z name), enjoyed being miserable. Despite being corrected again and again on their misbeliefs, they would resort right back to harboring on their anger/hatred/anxiousness over falsities. I felt their actions reflected a disregard for much of the advancements that came about from their mother's indirect contribution to medicine, but focused instead on a victim mentality and desire for monetary contribution - monetary contribution for something they had absolutely nothing to do with and had not worked for one iota.  As for the ethics surrounding Henrietta's cells being taken, be it right or wrong, she was not treated any differently than rich white patients were at that time when it came to taking cells/tissue without informed consent. In that sense, I don't think she was personally wronged in an intentional manner, though I think it's crazy what could be done without informed consent at that time. If you want to talk about who was wronged in an intentional manner, we'll talk about Elsie. Furthermore, I'm not completely convinced that some things were not explained to Henrietta regarding sampling cells. It was stated by Henrietta and the Lacks family time and again that they often came away with a poor understanding after speaking with MDs, yet they did not ask further questions or state their lack of understanding. Therefore, anytime it was exclaimed they were told "nothing", I had doubts. Henrietta's cells as they were taken, were of very little worth. It was the ingenuity of the people that used them that gave them their worth. Should Henrietta have received a modest compensation? Perhaps, it's muddled for me. Organ donors do not receive compensation (or their families). The reward is knowing you have saved other's lives. Should her children be entitled to compensation decades later for advancements that continue to be made 50 years after the cells were taken - cells that were not even from their own body? Definitely not. Is her family entitled to give permission for what can and cannot be done to Henrietta's cells? Absolutely not. Informed consent (which was not legally required at that time) is between the patient and the MD - what other family members wish is insignificant. The most interesting part of this story for me was easily Henrietta's story. Her childhood, the abuse of the time to the poor and minorities, the overt racist culture, and her strong optimistic nature that she maintained despite the world burning around her. The part that made the story a chore to finish was the ignorance that the family clung to despite being informed of truths, and the smallness with which they appreciated the lives that have been saved due to the awful cancer their mother acquired compared to the greatness with which they felt they deserved money as a result of research and ingenuity that they had never participated in, let alone understood. Azle - 7/16

This remarkable story about how people live on sometimes in the material way just as much as in memory, about science, ethics, the search for a cure to a potentially deadly disease, well, it's unforgettable and unlike any other book because it wasn't just her cells that kept Henrietta alive after her death - it was her family, whose lives were transformed upon hearing of her story and the research done on cells taken without her consent.
